creator: de_ulberg@yahoo.com
text:
It will be very nice to have mutable properties. To become mutable property 
has to be declared as mutable explicetely, e.g.:

<property name="t1" mutable="true"/>
or
<property name="t1" value="value" mutable="true"/>

Why do you need mutable properties?

Mutable properties make builds very difficult to control from external
environments (eg the command line, continuous integration tools, etc).
creator: conor@apache.org

text:
Dima,

I am going to close this as wontfix unless you can come up with a good argument
for mutability. Ant properties are not variables, and immutability is powerful,
once you get used to the 'whoever sets it first, wins' concept.
creator: stevel@apache.org

text:
If you _really_ need mutable properties, the Antelope distribution contains a
"variable" task derived from "property". "variable" is a mutable property and is
a drop-in replacement for "property". No need to rewrite Ant.
creator: danson@germane-software.com

text:
Antelope rocks
Note however that the installation manual should
read 
       
         <taskdef resource="ise/antelope/tasks/antelope.taskdefs
                  classpath="path/to/AntelopeTasks_2.55.jar"/>
rather than
       
         <taskdef resource="ise.antelope.tasks.antelope.taskdefs
                  classpath="path/to/AntelopeTasks_2.55.jar"/>

Also the name of the name of the variable task is "var".

example:

  <var name="x" value="6"/>
  <echo message="x is ${x}"/>
  <var name="x" value="7"/>
  <echo message="x is ${x}"/>
creator: peter.reilly@corvil.com

text:
OK, you have some workarounds if you want variables. Be forewarned, however,
that <var> makes it much more idfficult to control your build externally.
creator: conor@apache.org
